from numpy import *
from scipy.interpolate import *
from matplotlib.pyplot import *
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import pandas as pd
from scipy.stats import norm
import numpy as np
from sklearn import linear_model
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import statsmodels.api as sm
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf
import os

mydf['popularity'] = mydf.popularity.astype(float)
mydf['release_date'] = mydf.release_date.astype(float)
vote = mydf['vote_average']
budget = mydf['budget']
revenue = mydf['revenue']
runtime= mydf['runtime']
year = mydf['release_date']
popularity = mydf['popularity']

source:
#p1 = polyfit(revenue, budget, 1)
#print(p1)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
  
plot(vote, revenue, 'o')
plt.ylabel('Revenue', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Avg. Vote', fontsize=14)

p1 = polyfit(budget, revenue, 1)
#plot(budget, polyval(p1, budget), 'r-')
plot(budget, revenue, 'o')
plt.ylabel('Revenue', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Budget', fontsize=14)

plot(year, revenue, 'o')
plt.ylabel('Revenue', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Year', fontsize=14)

plot(runtime, revenue, 'o')
plt.ylabel('Revenue', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('Run Time', fontsize=14)

mu, std = norm.fit(vote)
plt.hist(vote, bins=15, normed=True, alpha=.5, color='g')
xmin, xmax = plt.xlim()
x = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, 100)
p = norm.pdf(x, mu, std)
plt.plot(x, p, 'k', linewidth=2)
title = "Fit Results for Avg. Vote: mu = %.2f,  std = %.2f, n = 4580" % (mu, std)
plt.title(title)
plt.xlabel('Average Vote')
plt.show()

mu, std = norm.fit(revenue)
plt.hist(revenue, bins=50, normed=True, alpha=.5, color='g')
xmin, xmax = plt.xlim()
x = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, 100)
p = norm.pdf(x, mu, std)
plt.plot(x, p, 'k', linewidth=2)
title = "Fit Results for Revenue: mu = %.2f,  std = %.2f, n = 4580" % (mu, std)
plt.title(title)
plt.xlabel('Revenue')
plt.show()

mu, std = norm.fit(runtime)
plt.hist(runtime, bins=15, normed=True, alpha=.5, color='g')
xmin, xmax = plt.xlim()
x = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, 100)
p = norm.pdf(x, mu, std)
plt.plot(x, p, 'k', linewidth=2)
title = "Fit Results for Run Time: mu = %.2f,  std = %.2f, n = 4580" % (mu, std)
plt.title(title)
plt.xlabel('Run Time')
plt.show()

mu, std = norm.fit(budget)
plt.hist(budget, bins=15, normed=True, alpha=.5, color='g')
xmin, xmax = plt.xlim()
x = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, 100)
p = norm.pdf(x, mu, std)
plt.plot(x, p, 'k', linewidth=2)
title = "Fit Results for Run Time: mu = %.2f,  std = %.2f, n = 4580" % (mu, std)
plt.title(title)
plt.xlabel('Budget')
plt.show()

#plt.figure()
#plt.boxplot(vote)
#plt.ylabel('Vote')

#plt.figure()
#plt.boxplot(revenue)
#plt.ylabel('Revenue')

#plt.figure()
#plt.boxplot(runtime)
#plt.ylabel('Run Time')

dfx = pd.DataFrame(mydf.revenue)
dfy = pd.DataFrame(mydf.runtime)
regr = linear_model.LinearRegression()
model = regr.fit(dfx,dfy)
regr.score(dfx,dfy)
regr.intercept_
predictions = regr.predict(dfx)
print(predictions)

#Linear Regression for Budget
x= budget
x = sm.add_constant(x, prepend=True)

results = smf.OLS(revenue, x).fit()
print(results.summary())

#Linear Regression for Run Time
x= runtime
x = sm.add_constant(x, prepend=True)

results = smf.OLS(revenue, x).fit()
print(results.summary())

#Linear Regression for Release Year
x= year
x = sm.add_constant(x, prepend=True)

results = smf.OLS(revenue, x).fit()
print(results.summary())

source:
#Linear Regression for Vote
x= vote
x = sm.add_constant(x, prepend=True)

results = smf.OLS(revenue, x).fit()
print(results.summary())

#Multiple Linear Regression for all variables
x= np.column_stack((budget,vote,year, runtime))
x = sm.add_constant(x, prepend=True)

results = smf.OLS(revenue, x).fit()
print(results.summary())

#Breusch Pagan Test for Hetroscedasticity
import statsmodels

name = ['Lagrange Multiplier Statistic', 'p-value', 'f-value', 'f p-value']
bp = statsmodels.stats.diagnostic.het_breushpagan(results.resid, results.model.exog)
bp
pd.DataFrame(name,bp)

# Since our p value is less than .05, it suggests that our test does have hetroscedasticity.
